text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: FRANK S. ANDERSON

Present Address: BRIARLEA

Pioneer Address: " "

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1907

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

NO. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days? Any time?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? With or without notice?

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Sometimes we helped each other with work.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together in a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst driving or dancing in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a month, etc.? After hall was built they were held in hall and staged all night.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

RECREATION VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the last few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many homes were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? About 3-4 times.

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Often.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Invited or visited.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That day, was the term to make polite used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Tea.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "cook after the places"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? After hall was built they were held in the house.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, poinsettias, etc., if you have not described these on the school questionnaire.) Olive Bates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Next around the School

Then the Hall.

9. When was your first community hall built? About 1920 in the School.

What material was it made of? Concrete. How large was it? 40' x 20'.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Colletta.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it in a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social entertainments and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you also use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? In the house. No provision in the hall.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? Yes.

What dances were popular? Fox Trot.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Will accept Card Playing but not Gambling
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. Include also the school Christmas tree, plans, etc.

If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, Olive Daley.

1915-6/1920 in the School

Next around the School

Then the Hall

9. When was your first community hall built? About 1915-6

What material was it made of? Wood

For large was it? 40' x 20'

Who built it? The community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.

Collection in

Was it built in the village town or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you come to town for district meetings and did you use the hall for all gatherings?)

Did you have to turn the school house over for other purposes? Or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9, 9a, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were tables and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? Yes

What dances were popular? Square

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Will accept card playing but not gambling
12. What attempts at formality or "snack" do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visiting cards ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the obituary known in your community? Describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

None

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments mentioned that were popular in parties and social life during the twenties. You can also mention changes in visiting or social life since then.

During first world war, Red Cross dances, which became popular.

Red Cross was organized for second world war.

Red Cross very active all through twenties.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Field day at a local fair - field day.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What etiquette at formality or "snack" do you remember in small towns such as Glencoe and Butte when calling, calling cards, visiting ladies' tea parties, etc.?

13. Was the dance known in your community? Describe what you remember about it, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of dancing, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or dances not mentioned that you were popular at parties and what you remember doing whenever you can when none change.

15. What was the name of the first organization or any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was centered in one relatively large area (for example, within a county). (There is space in the chart given below for organizations connected with the church so they need not be included here).

Nothing named organized before 1915

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Owner's School House

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

When? Nov. 1, 1915

What subject was most frequently discussed?

Who came often with lectures?

Did you often have magic lantern shows?

Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

That games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village (for example, the church or reading community). There is space in the chart for names of five organizations.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes

21. Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumble type, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - skating, snowballing, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Mushers" or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS:

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. 

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

In the afternoon we ended up with a dance at night.
22. What winter games were played outside? 
   - Snowball fights, sledging, etc.

What games were played indoors in winter—card games such as "Happy Family," "Murmurs" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, rocks, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICTURES AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?
   - Date: 1915

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, social organization, etc.?
   - School

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?
   - Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?
   - Ball games, boating on the lake

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?
   - General lunch. Every family brought something

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
   - Salads, sandwiches, tea, coffee

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
   - In the forenoon it ended up with a dance at night.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc., and differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

They used to be more & pulled more

We needed by how much it had for how little

My idea much fun is had for how little

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people), ball games, races, tug war, etc.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1929

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving data of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities, played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this piano which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of pianos which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community piano, school or Sunday School pianos, family pianos, etc., tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, music heard, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in pianos since the first years? Give dates when changes became noticeable.

They were more popular and needed less.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

ball games, races, tag races.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving data of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities, where played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
7. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Early 1920.

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? No.

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

Was there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

8. Was there a school library? Yes.

When was it begun? 1912

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? A little

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material? I don't know.
7. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 

8. Did it grow out of or explain the earlier community plans? 

9. Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? 

10. What was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). 

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. 

READING 

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary) 

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? 

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? 

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details. 

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? 

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? 

48. Was there a school library? 

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts as additional reading material? 

When was it begun? 

Yes 

A little 

Yes
8.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   In it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you dropped our—no padding now—subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
8.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this area?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you dropped certain publications and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west? Explain.
Musical Entertainment.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (were there musical contests or was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Instrumentation

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music" or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or take up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, describe them.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.
